Write-up: Hotline TNT

Album: Desire, I Want To Turn Into You
Write-up: Caroline's post-Chairlift output has seen her embracing synthesized ultra-pop, while continuining to flex her incredible vocal range. Desire features less of previous album Pang's PC Music collaboration, but Caroline's own production more than fills the gap in the last half of the album.

Trading the stochastic and crunchy noise of 2021's To See the Next Part of The Dream for streamlined melodies and vocals brings Parannoul's songcraft into the focus. Adding texture in this more traditional way gives the album room to breath and tell a more varied story with new varying instrumentation.

The year of the boy comes to a close with a phenomenal, mainstream crossover smash from boygenius. What started as a passion project from three, quietly adored singer-songwriters exploded into a worldwise sensation and the record reflects the hyper focus necessary to spend a year making music and touring with your supergroup like this. Also it's wonderfully sapphic and I know my friends like that, and I really appreciate all the silly little outfits they put Julien into this year.

Don't waste your pearls on me is echoed across album powerhouse song "Turbines/Pigs", ten minutes long and set against beautiful and wandering piano notes. BCNR were forced to reinvent themselves after the departure of frontman Isaac Woods, but have metamorphised into a tender new sound cut through with their old intensity.
Wednesday mixes styles and influences seamlessly, bouncing between classic indie and noisy shoegazes with effortless aplomb. All this to craft a dark album with a laser focus.

I spent my fair share of the last couple years beating my friends over the head with this band's 2021 EP, I Became Birds. Technically their first LP, the whaler brings out the expertly crafted stochastic emo of Home Is Where to paint portraits of every kind of modern angst.

The most ascendant DJSTTDJ collection, an album of such length and power it transcends the medium, finds Sabrina in the throes of crafting seamless beats for almost four hours. Any song can be played at any moment, which is necessary to try to even fit this album into one's daily life, and a wave of comforting, stimulating dance music will follow. Somehow, inhumanly, full of bangers from start to finish.
This album made me emotionally attached to windows.

Jeff Rosenstock has long since transcended ska punk, finding himself at the nexus of cathartic indie while still mixing the ska tinged anthems he's known for. Few albums this year have captured the utter chaos we are forced to confront every day, but HELLMODE smashes right into that with room to contemplate our deepest of feelings too.

Album: The Land Is Inhospitable and So Are We
Write-up: Having mature alongside the earlier Mitski works, I often suffer whiplash from the quality of the later releases. Mitski rarely reinvents her sound, every album is an incremental step forward and each one cements her songcraft further.

It is 2023, I am enraptured by Sufjan's combination of experimentation and personal expression. It is 2015, I am enraptured by Sufjan's combination of experimentation and personal expression. It is 2010, I am enraptured by Sufjan's combination of experimentation and personal expression.
Arriving at a hodgepodge of shoegaze-cum-rock with insanely distorted instrumentation and hushed vocals, Jane Remover builds a rich but empty void on Census Designated.

Album: My Back Was A Bridge For You To Cross
Write-up: I've loved ANOHNI since 2016's HOPELESSNESS, and working again with Antony and the Johnsons to craft a spell-binding and emotionally raw album filled me with delight.

Olivia has done what so many have tried and so few have succeeded at: no longer being a Disney kid. GUTS represents an obvious depature from the mouse, but it really shines as a synthesis of pop and pop-adjacent genres to create an insanely fun and listenable album.

Some might say this duo trends closer to dream pop, but for me it feels like The Cure reincarnate. Whistful vocals and otherworldly melodies remind me of classic new wave sounds, and I found this album innately listenable.
All it takes is one minute of listening to Militarie Gun before the first "OOH OOH" shatters your ego and it's all over from there.
Love to see YLT back at, a classic band that works together so seamlessly every new album is almost an instant classic for them.

My achilles heel incarnate, every time something gecs comes out I think to myself "I'm past the gecs, I'm an adult and responsible snake parent, I don't need hyperpop this badly." And I'm wrong; I need this shit, it is full of bangers and silly lines and music that tickles my lizard brain. A good time is infectious, and 100 gecs always know how to deliver that have-fun virus.

Yvette Young brings all of her guitar playing virtuoso to bear in catharsis. Melodies move beyond comprehension and the listener is left to wonder how this degree of skill is acquired, let alone utilized to effectively on an album as pretty and deep as this one.
Feist contains Multitudes.

Album: In The End It Always Does
Write-up: The Japanese House has perfected their pop ambitions with In The End It Always Does and put together a salvo of hits in their ephemeral, sunshine-on-a-breezy-day style.
Massachusetts hardcore outfit Fiddlehead mince no words and waste no time on Death Is Nothing To Us, indulging in the anxiety and reprieve that only the best hardcore bands can summon.

While I agree this album wasn't as stupendous as their eoponymous hiatus ender, Slowdive still continues to perfect the genre they helped found and codify and I find this additional to their canon almost as compelling as the last.

OPN uses Again to embrace the ambient electronic soundscapes his albums are wont for. But in the crevaces of drum machines and synths lie melodies and motifs that bind the songs together and call forth one's attention in a way standard ambient music cannot.
